moves.1... a5: I reviewed black's past games and noticed a recent loss with this opening move when his opponent ignored the rook pawn all the way to axb2 followed by bishop capture. I didn't understand much of the game and not sure if the pawn loss was pivotal, but maybe I can do the same thing. I think he's trying to provoke me into something I'll regret. (post game note: plenty of that later)
moves.2. Nc3 a4: Wait.... what if he doesn't capture b2 and just sits there? Hold on, that was a recent game, he probably won't do that again. Why didn't I move c4 again?
moves.3. a3: so I push c3, no apparent resolve to stick to my plan. After I click move, this looks really ugly.
moves.3... Nc6 4. g3: post game note: analysis shows this as an inaccuracy, but I intended on the fianchetto and wanted to castle as soon as possible. Not sure why its an inaccuracy.
moves.4... e5 5. e4 d6: I don't really know the name of this board configuration, but have seen it a lot. Seems like the d6 blocks in his black bishop. So maybe he's going to fianchetto his bishop.
moves.6. Bb5: Since his pawn is on c4, I can hold this pin for a while to make him uncomfortable.
moves.6... Be7: Why not g6 and then Bg7? Seems like this blocks in the queen, but I think he's castling short.
moves.7. d4: I thought about Nxa4, but thought he would advance on d file. I also didn't want to give up the pinned knight position yet.
moves.7... exd4 8. Nxd4 Bd7 9. Nxc6: I see an opportunity to get his pawns doubled, seems like maybe that will be an advantage. I need every one I can get. Also, I read somewhere that a fianchetto is easy to defeat when the opponent has the queen and bishop with the same color as your fianchetto bishop. I think if I take his bishop with mine, I may be able to defend better. Maybe another advantage.
moves.9... Bxc6 10. Bxc6+: (post game note: I think giving up my white bishop was a big mistake)
moves.10... bxc6 11. O-O Bf6 12. Qf3: Not quite sure what to do next. I decide to target the only unprotected piece, c6. I'll move e5 next and take his bishop. Unless I missed something, there's a fork at Qc6 there he'll have to defend.
moves.12... Ne7: I guess he saw that as well.
moves.13. Ne2: So, I decide to do something about a4. (post game note: I have a feeling this is where I made my big error, but analysis doesn't really say much. Would appreciate opinions here.)
moves.13... O-O 14. Rb1 Ng6 15. Kg2: I remember he has no white bishop and wanted to move my king to that color thinking it will be safer. (post game note: waste of two moves)
moves.15... Qe7 16. b3: back to dealing with a4 (post game note: totally unconcerned with the obviously threatening queen)
moves.16... Rfe8: wait... that suddenly looks very unhealthy.
moves.17. Kg1: I shouldn't have moved there in the first place.
moves.17... Qxe4: clearly he wants me the exchange... how can I get out of this in the best shape? (post game note: it never really crossed my mind that he might be looking at my rook, bishop, and pawn just hanging around behind the lines. I wish I had developed these a bit, pesky a4 pawn!)
moves.18. Qe3: now I think I can deal with an exchange here.
moves.19. Rb2: I'll threaten his queen and then get mine out of the way, rather lose a rook than my queen.
moves.19... Bxb2 20. Re1: (post game note: distracted and forgot my save-the-queen plan)
moves.20... Rxe3 21. Bxe3: mediocre defense, but absolutely no offense now. At this point, would have resigned, but I wanted to see if I can make it to 30 moves.
moves.21... Ne5 22. Nd4 Bxd4 23. Rc1 Nf3+: didn't see that, 30 moves seems like it might be unreachable
moves.24. Kg2 Qe4 25. Kf1: of the three choices this seems best, but the end is near.
moves.25... Bxe3 26. Rc3 Nd4 27. Rxe3 Qh1#: RIP, next time to 30 moves Freddy!
